newsitem.title: UK: Lloyds TSB to star again in UK bank results.
newsitem.headline: Lloyds TSB to star again in UK bank results.

text.p: Lloyds TSB Group Plc, which reports its first half results next Friday, is set to retain its position as the best performer in the UK banking sector.

Pre-tax profits are set to rise by around one third to above 1.5 billion pounds, after 1.14 billion in the same period last year, while a dividend per share of 5.0p compared with 4.2p last time will give growth of 19 percent.
"It's again going to be the star performer," said Nikko Europe banking analyst Tim Clarke. "But its rating is hugely expensive on all measure."
Lloyds looks set to report a hefty fall in costs, unlike most others, and its high ratings are easily justified by the quality of its earnings stream, analysts said.

"Lloyds has been the best performer in the sector, its highly cash-generative business will ensure it soon accumulates enough cash to make other, value-enhancing, deals," said UBS analyst John Aitken.
Costs are expected fall by at least five percent as the bank reaps the rewards of its merger with TSB and internal cost cutting.
In the banking business, the group is expected to have found it just as tough as its peers to increase income, however, with margins under pressure and fee income growth lacklustre.
Like the others, Lloyds will benefit from consumer credit growth with good growth, for example, in credit cards.
The market will be looking for some indication from chairman Brian Pitman and chief executive Peter Ellwood on where Lloyds TSB will go from here.
Its ability to generate cash means that a further value-enhancing merger or takeover must be a major possibility despite the fact that Pitman has said prices are too high.
Indeed, Nikko's Clarke says its is imperative that Lloyds pursues this strategy.
"Lloyds TSB will only remain the leader if its goes for another merger," Clarke said.
